Award.AwardTitle: Underrepresented Students in Topology and Algebra Research Symposium
Award.AbstractNarration:
The Underrepresented Students in Topology and Algebra Research Symposium (USTARS 2017) will take place March 31-April 2, 2017 at Amherst College, in Amherst, Massachusetts. The symposium will highlight research being conducted by underrepresented students in the areas of algebra and topology. Most speakers will give thirty-minute research talks in parallel sessions. Graduate students will give at least three-quarters of these presentations. Two distinguished graduate students and one invited faculty member will be chosen to give one-hour presentations. A poster session featuring invited undergraduates, a panel discussion, and a professional development session are also planned. USTARS exposes participants to the research and activities of underrepresented mathematicians, encouraging a more collaborative mathematics community. Participants are also given the opportunity to meet and network with students and faculty members who will later become collaborators and colleagues.

At this unique meeting, attendees are exposed to a great variety of current research, ideas, and results in their areas of study and beyond. The topics of the presentations will vary over a wide range of areas in algebra and topology. There will be parallel sessions focused on combinatorics, number theory, commutative algebra, algebraic geometry, associative algebras, nonassociative rings and algebras, group theory and generalizations, topological groups and Lie groups, general topology, algebraic topology, and manifolds and cell complexes. Further details may be found on the conference website at http://www.ustars.org.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This award funded participant travel to USTARS 2017 at Amherst College and USTARS 2018 at Reed College.  The primary mission of the Underrepresented Students in Topology and Algebra Research Symposium (USTARS) is to showcase the excellent research conducted by underrepresented students studying topology and algebra. Dedicated to furthering the success of underrepresented students, USTARS seeks to broaden the participation in the mathematical sciences by cultivating research and mentoring networks. USTARS is open to all people interested in the topological and algebraic fields.

 

USTARS 2017 welcomed over 84 participants and showcased the excellent research being conducted by underrepresented graduate students by including 15 half-hour oral presentations in three parellel-sessions and 22 poster presentations in research areas including, but not limited to, AMS Subject Classification codes: 05 Combinatorics, 11 Number Theory, 13 Commutative Algebra, 14 Algebraic Geometry, 16 Associative Algebras, 17 Nonassociative Rings and Algebra, 20 Group Theory and Generalizations,  22 Topological Groups, Lie Groups, 54 General Topology, 55 Algebra Topology, and 57 Manifolds and Cell Complexes. All 15 of the talks were presented by graduate students and all 22 posters were presented by undergraduate and graduate students.

USTARS 2017 opened with a one-day early career faculty development workshop on "Writing Through Your Career."  Through a series of panels and discussions, participants were provided with information and advice on grantwriting, forming writing groups to create accountability, and compiling and writing tenure and promotion portofolios.  The conference also included two 1-hour presentations delivered by Distinguished Graduate Students whose abstracts were selected by an external committee of reviewers.  Robert Walker, a graduate student at the University of Michigan, lectured on the "Uniform Asymptotic Growth on Symbolic Powers of Ideals," and Bahar Acu, a graduate student at the University of Southern California talked about "Symplectic mapping class group relations generalizing the chain relation." The Invited Faculty Mentor was Dr. Chelsea Walton, Selma Lee Bloch Brown Assistant Professor at Temple University. She gave an inspiring address on "Math in the Age of Trump."

 USTARS 2018 showcased the excellent research conducted by underrepresented graduate students to over 50 participants through 15 half-hour talks in three parallel sessions and a poster session including 11 poster presentations. These talks covered research areas including, but not limited to, AMS Subject Classfication codes: 05 Combinatorics, 11 Number Theory, 13 Commutative Algebra, 14 Algebraic Geometry, 16 Associative Algebras, 17 Nonassociative Rings and Algebra, 20 Group Theory and Generalizations, 22 Topological Groups, Lie Groups, 54 General Topology, 55 Algebraic Topology, and 57 Manifolds and Cell Complexes. 14 of the 15 talks were presented by graduate students, and all 11 posters were presented by graduate and undergraduate students.

The conference also featured two 1-hour presentations delivered by Distinguished Graduate Student Speakers whose abstracts were selected by an external committee of reviewers. Clifford Bridges, a graduate at the University of Colorado – Boulder was the Distinguished Speaker in Algebra; his talk was titled “Embedding Problems over ZZ_p with Kernel ZZ_{p^2}^n.” Eva Elduque, a graduate student at the University of Wisconsin – Madison, was the Distinguished Speaker in Topology; her talk was titled “On the signed Euler characteristic property for subvarieties of abelian varieties.” The Invited Faculty Mentor was Jose Perea, Assistant Professor at Michigan State University. His keynote address was on “Some applications of topology to data science.” Thanks to continued NSF support, the conference was able to provide full travel support to all graduate and undergraduate student presenters, and partial travel support to general participants


Both conferences featured professional development panels where participants were invited to ask for advice on how to apply to graduate schools, find jobs, give great presentations, and become active in research opportunities.  The professional development panels consisted of groups of faculty and students of diverse backgrounds, career stages, and academic experiences. 

One of the most important outcomes of each USTARS conference is that participants are encouraged to develop a network of mentors and peers that will serve as a vital resource for collaboration and professional development throughout their careers.  The networks of new connections made at USTARS 2017 is included as a supporting image to this report.
